Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Fractals, Multifractals, and Stochastic Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stochastic partial differential equations (SPDE) are employed to model a wide range of natural phenomena and play a central role in various areas of pure and applied mathematics, mathematical oceanography, stochastic hydrology, geo-statistics, and mathematical physics. This research project is concerned with the development of an analytic/geometric theory of random fields, primarily those that arise from SPDE. The project aims to develop probabilistic, analytic, and geometric tools that will lead to a deeper understanding of physically-relevant random fields. It is anticipated that these tools will have sufficient novelty to open new research areas, solve a number of long-standing open problems in the theory of SPDE and related random fields, and further promote their applicability. The project involves graduate students in the research.

It is significant and challenging to characterize the fine local and asymptotic structures of SPDE and related random fields. In past work, the investigators developed ideas, based in geometric-measure theory, for the analysis of non-Markovian Gaussian and stable random fields, and they introduced renewal-theoretic and coupling techniques for the asymptotic analysis of solutions to a large class of nonlinear SPDE. This research project continues investigation of precise quantitative connections between random fields, potential theory, SPDE, and the geometry of random fractals. Special emphasis is placed on two extremal universality classes of SPDE that are driven by fully non-linear multiplicative noise. Further pursuit of these connections is expected to yield novel insights into the structure of random fields, physical multifractals, and related SPDE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the award period (August 2016--July 2020) the Proposers have established a series of significant results on analysis of stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs) and random fields. These include macroscopic multifractal analysis, asymptotic and local properties,  potential theory and geometry of the solutions of two extremal universality classes of SPDEs that are driven by fully non-linear multiplicative noise, and excursion probabilities of Gaussian random fields. The PIs have developed original methods for solving several outstanding open problems on SPDEs  and random fields.  The research of the Proposers has led to deeper understanding of SPDEs and random fields and will further promote their applicability in various scientific areas such as mathematical physics, geostatistics, oceanography, cosmology, hydrology, just to mention a few.

The discoveries of Professor Xiao have been published in more than thirty articles in peer reviewed journals and presented at national and international conferences or at seminars in universities in the U.S. and abroad. 

The past works of Professor Xiao demonstrate a strong commitment to the identification and career development of young talent in the mathematical sciences. Professor Xiao has integrated new discoveries in his research into student training and into courses that he taught at Michigan State University, as well as short courses that he taught in summer schools at Northwestern University in the U.S., the CIMPA Research School in Argentina, the South China University of Technology in China, and L'Universite Lille in France.  

Professor Xiao has supervised two Ph.D. students [Dr.  Jeonghwa Lee (2019), Dr. Cheuk Yin Lee (2020)]. This NSF grant provided one semester 1/2 support  for Jeonghwa Lee  and one semester 1/2 support for Cheuk Yin Lee to conduct their dissertation research. He has  mentored six visiting  post-doctoral scholars [Dr.s L. Fang, H. He, Y. Huo,  N. Luan, G. Yang, and X. Yang]. 

The PI Xiao has helped to organize a number of activities related to the topics of their NSF-funded research. Those activities include Special Session on ``Gaussian Random Fields: Theory and Applications'' at the IMS-China International Conference in Statistics and Probability (2017, 2019); Scientific Committee member of the ``Workshop on Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Analysis" at Zhejiang Gongshang University  (2018); ``Workshop on Gaussian Processes and Related Topics" at East China Normal University (2019); and ``Seminar on Stochastic Processes" (2020). Professor Xiao is Co-Editor in Chief of Statistics and Probability Letters, a managing editor of Journal of Fractal Geometry, and serves on hte editorial boards Illinois Journal of Mathematics and Science China Mathematics.
